question: Why is a runners heart rate lower than a non runner
answers: A runner’s heart rate is lower than a non-runner’s because of increased cardiovascular fitness.
Regular running and other endurance activities cause real physical changes to the heart, such as an increased size and thicker heart wall muscles.
This increased efficiency allows the heart to pump more blood with each beat, meaning it requires fewer beats to deliver the same amount of blood throughout the body.
Additionally, running increases vagal tone, which suppresses heart rate.
Therefore, an athlete’s resting heart rate is usually lower than other people.
While this can be beneficial and a sign of improved cardiovascular fitness, it can also lead to misdiagnosis of serious heart problems if the athlete is not aware of their condition.

question: Why are there only circular planets? Why can't there be square or rectangular ones?
answers: The planets in our solar system are shaped like spheres because of the force of gravity.
When the planets first formed, they were made up of billions of pieces of dust and gas that collided with each other and slowly grew larger.
As they did, the force of these collisions caused them to become hot and molten and the gravitational force from their core pulled all the material into a spherical shape.
This process is known as "isostatic adjustment."
Even though gravity conspires to make the planets spherical, the speed of their rotation can also cause them to become oblate spheroids, which means that they are slightly flattened at the poles.

Since the gravitational pull of the planets is not strong enough to overcome the mechanical strength of smaller bodies, such as asteroids, they do not form spheres but rather maintain irregular, fragmentary shapes.
This means that planets are the only bodies in our solar system that have a circular shape.

In addition, a square or rectangular planet is impossible because there would need to be an external force acting on it to keep it in that shape, which is not possible due to the lack of gravity in space.

question: what causes the center of ice to whiten?
answers: The center of ice cubes whitens because the last parts of the ice cube to crystallize end up with most of the impurities.

As the water freezes, it wants to form a regular crystalline structure (ice) and the impurities like oxygen and other dissolved gasses are pushed away from the crystallization front into the remaining liquid.
This means that the impurities that were evenly distributed in the water, tend to congregate near the middle, making the ice cubes the whitest at their center.
The main reason is that the (hopefully) crystal-clear water you pour into the ice trays is not as pure as it seems, containing small amounts of (hopefully) harmless suspended minerals and sediment.
Because all objects freeze from the outside in, the center of the cube is the last to solidify.
Water free of minerals and impurities freezes first, pushing the cloudy parts containing the sediment (and tiny trapped air bubbles) toward the center.
The result is a harmless (but not particularly photogenic) ice cube clouding.

question: If I were to create a company, have $1M debt, go bankrupt, how would the company that I owe get its money ? do I have to pay ?
answers: If you create a company, have $1M debt, and go bankrupt, the company that you owe can take action to recover the money.
Depending on the type of debt, the company may be able to pursue the loan through a lender or by piercing the corporate veil.
If you cosigned on a business loan, you are as equally responsible as the corporation or LLC to pay it back.
If you personally guaranteed the debt, the creditor can come after your personal assets if the business defaults on the loan.
If the company that you owe files for bankruptcy, the court will instruct you where to make your monthly payments if that changes.
If you have any dispute over whether the debt is valid, raise that dispute as soon as you are notified of the bankruptcy.
If you don’t, the debt may be considered valid and you may be required to pay it back.
Additionally, if you are found to have committed fraud, the company that you owe can take action to hold you personally liable for the debt.

question: Why do we use air filled tires and not tires made of solid rubber, that don't run the risk of going flat?
answers: Air filled tires are commonly used in vehicles because they provide better cushioning and shock absorption than tires made of solid rubber, which makes them more comfortable to drive on.
Air filled tires also have a lighter weight than solid rubber tires, which reduces the engine load and improves fuel efficiency.
Additionally, air filled tires provide a medium for contraction and expansion of the tire, which reduces the wear and tear caused by friction of the rubber with the rim of the wheel.
Finally, air filled tires do not run the risk of going flat, which is an added benefit as flat tires can be a major inconvenience.
All these qualities make air filled tires much more suitable for use in vehicles than tires made of solid rubber.

question: Why do VGA/DVI cables have to be screwed in, but HDMI and other cables don't?
answers: VGA/DVI cables are much more fragile than other cables like HDMI, so they need to be screwed in for additional stability and to prevent accidental disconnection.
The pins on VGA/DVI connectors are small and easily damaged if not secured properly, so the additional physical holding pressure provided by the screws is necessary.
Furthermore, the power cables are much thicker and physically stronger than video connectors, so they don't need to be screwed in.
However, HDMI cables and other cables do not need to be screwed in because they have much stronger conductors and connectors, making it much more difficult to accidentally disconnect them.

question: Why do different European languages have such varying names for Germany?
answers: Different European languages have such varying names for Germany because of the long history of the region and its many different inhabitants.
Throughout its history, Germany has been occupied by various tribes, such as the Alemanni, Saxons, and Germanic people.
When the Roman Empire began taking over Europe, the Latin term for the area inhabited by the Germanic tribes was 'Germania'.
Meanwhile, in Scandinavian languages, like Danish and Swedish, the term 'Tyskland' was used, and in Dutch, 'Duitsland'.

In the Slavic languages, like Polish and Czech, the term 'Niemcy' was used, which derived from the Proto-Slavic word 'němьcь', meaning 'mute', as it was used to describe foreigners who couldn't speak the local language.

Finally, the Baltic languages like Latvian and Lithuanian have terms like 'Vācija' and 'Vokietija', which are thought to have derived from the Proto-Indo-European word 'wek', meaning 'to speak', or from terms used for the Vikings.
Thus, due to the region's long and varied history, different languages have different names for Germany.

question: Why does a cold plastic bottle of water sweat?
answers: A cold plastic bottle of water sweats because when warm air comes in contact with the cold surface of the bottle, it reaches its dew point and condenses.
This causes the water vapor in the air to cool down, condense and form tiny beads of liquid on the outside of the bottle.
This phenomenon is known as condensation.
Condensation happens when the air is cooled to its dew point or it becomes so saturated with water vapor that it cannot hold any more water.
The molecules in these miniscule droplets of water are grouped far more closely together than when they were in their gas phase, and exert less pressure.
This is why we often see water droplets on the outside of cold cans, glasses of cold water and other cold surfaces.

question: How can someone put me in to jail if i am not guilty?
answers: It is unfortunately possible to be wrongfully convicted and sent to jail even if you are innocent.
The rate of wrongful convictions in the United States is estimated to be between 2 and 10 percent, which means that there are potentially hundreds of thousands of innocent people who are in jail.
There are several potential causes of wrongful convictions.
One is bad police work, where some officers may hide, alter, or fabricate evidence, or lie on the stand, to wrongly convict someone.
Another is prosecutorial misconduct, where some prosecutors may hide exculpatory evidence or encourage witnesses to commit perjury, in order to convict an innocent person.
Finally, false confessions, where someone may confess to a crime they didn't commit under the pressure of an intense interrogation, can also lead to wrongful convictions.
In these cases, it is possible for someone to be sent to jail even if they are innocent.

question: Why oil and gas rigs may cause earthquake and falls?
answers: Oil and gas extraction can cause earthquakes in the central United States due to the injection of wastewater into disposal wells.
This process, known as fracking, involves the high-pressure injection of a mix of water, sand, and chemicals into underground rock to release oil and gas.
The wastewater that is produced is then disposed of in injection wells, or sometimes disposal wells.
This process can cause earthquakes as the injected fluids migrate and cause pressure changes in the surrounding rocks.
In fact, studies have shown that twenty percent of the earthquakes in the central United States could be attributed to just four of the wells.
Furthermore, Keranen et al.
have shown that the steep rise in earthquakes in Oklahoma, USA, is likely caused by fluid migration from wastewater disposal wells.
This fluid migration can even trigger earthquakes over 30 km away.
Therefore, oil and gas extraction can be linked to an increase in seismic activity and, as a result, can potentially lead to falls and other damage.

question: Why am I unstable on my bike when it's stationary but not when it's moving?
answers: When stationary, a bicycle is statically unstable because it only has two contact points with the ground and its base of support is a line segment, which is not enough to keep it upright.
A good base of support needs three contact points.

Additionally, when a bicycle is not moving, its wheels are not spinning and thus have zero angular momentum, making it easy for external torque to change the wheels' direction and making it harder to balance.

However, when a bicycle is moving, it is dynamically stable because the rider is able to move the bike's points of support around under the center of gravity and keep it balanced with small steering adjustments.

This is possible because the spinning wheels of the bicycle have angular momentum, and when the rider is sitting on the bike, they and the wheels make up a system that obeys the principle of conservation of angular momentum.

As long as torque, or twisting force, is not applied from outside the system to change the wheels' angular momentum, the momentum and the direction of the momentum remain constant, making it easier to keep the bike balanced.
The new study in Science claims that the gyroscopic effects and trail of the bicycle do help its stability, but are not necessary above a certain speed.

question: Scientifically speaking , how likely is it that our existence is extremely small?
answers: Scientifically speaking, the likelihood of our existence is extremely small.
The Rare Earth hypothesis argues that the evolution of biological complexity anywhere in the universe requires the coincidence of a large number of fortuitous circumstances.
This includes a galactic habitable zone; a central star and planetary system having the requisite character (i.e.

a circumstellar habitable zone); a terrestrial planet of the right mass; the advantage of one or more gas giant guardians like Jupiter and possibly a large natural satellite to shield the planet from frequent impact events; conditions needed to ensure the planet has a magnetosphere and plate tectonics; a chemistry similar to that present in the Earth's lithosphere, atmosphere, and oceans; the influence of periodic "evolutionary pumps" such as massive glaciations and bolide impacts; and whatever factors may have led to the emergence of eukaryotic cells, sexual reproduction, and the Cambrian explosion of animal, plant, and fungi phyla.
Furthermore, the evolution of human beings and of human intelligence may have required yet further specific events and circumstances, all of which are extremely unlikely to have happened.
Therefore, it can be said that the likelihood of our existence is extremely small and a product of many unique and fortuitous circumstances.

question: Why do fish that live around coral reefs appear to be more colorful than fish that don't live around coral reefs?
answers: Fish that live around coral reefs appear to be more colorful than those that don't for a variety of reasons.
The first is that the bright colors allow them to blend in with their environment, providing camouflage from predators.
This theory was first suggested by Alfred Russel Wallace in the 19th century.
The second is that the colors are used for species recognition, allowing them to identify their own species in the crowded reef environment.
Konrad Lorenz proposed this idea in the mid-20th century, noting that the intricate color pattern of some reef fish allowed them to differentiate between individuals.
Additionally, by having distinct color patterns, fish can minimize the costs of aggression, since they don't have to compete with other species.
Finally, some fish use light conditions to communicate signals – such as mating, camouflage, and territory – in a way that matches the clarity of the water.
This is especially true in the Pacific, where there is not as much light, so fish rely more on color information than spatial information.
Overall, the bright colors of fish that live around coral reefs allow them to blend in with their environment, recognize their own species, and communicate with each other in the surrounding water.

question: Why does the President of the United States need to be born in the United States to be eligible to run?
answers: The framers of the Constitution had several reasons why they wanted the President of the United States to be born in the United States in order to be eligible to run.
They feared the potential of foreign influence and interference in the election and governance of the nation.
They also wanted to protect the nation against dynastic scheming, which was common in Europe.
They were familiar with the example of Poland, where agents from other countries had installed a friendly monarch and then used his weakness to partition the country among themselves.
Furthermore, they were aware of the case of England’s King George I, who was a Hanoverian who spoke no English.

In order to protect the nation from such scenarios, George Mason argued for restrictions on foreign officeholders, stating that he did not want “foreigners and adventurers” to make laws for the country or for “rich foreign nations” to “send over her tools who might bribe their way” into federal office.

Similarly, John Jay wrote a letter to George Washington suggesting that it would be wise to provide a “strong check” to the admission of foreigners into the national government, and to declare that the command of the American army shall not be given to anyone but a “natural born” citizen.
These concerns were reflected in Article II, Section I of the Constitution, which states that the President must be a “natural born” citizen.
This requirement was meant to ensure that the President was a native of the United States and had no ties to foreign governments or interests.
By requiring that the President of the United States be born in the United States, the framers sought to protect the nation against foreign influence and interference.

question: Why do some planets form rings while others form moons?
answers: The exact answer to why some planets form rings while others form moons is still a matter of scientific dispute, although there are a few theories that explain it.

One theory suggests that the rings are formed from material that is too close to the planet for it to coalesce into a moon due to its gravitational pull, so it spreads out in orbit around the planet as a ring instead.
Another idea is that a close call by a moon or comet results in the planet’s gravitational tidal force breaking up those bodies, the debris of which then becomes a ring system.
The giant planets, such as Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune, formed much farther away from the Sun than the terrestrial planets, such as Mercury, Venus, Earth, and Mars.

This larger volume of space and lower gravity of the Sun in the giant-planet region allowed them to form like solar systems in miniature, pulling in lots of material and having a disk of gas, dust, and ice surrounding them during formation.
Any dust or ice not incorporated into the planet itself would have coalesced into the regular moons we see today around the giant planets.

The terrestrial planets, on the other hand, formed much closer to the Sun with much less material around them, and they grew slowly by accreting many small rocky planetesimals and never grew massive enough to capture a disk of gas and dust.
Earth’s Moon probably formed through a direct collision, as any large object striking a planet would have thrown material off the world into orbit, allowing it to coalesce into a moon.

question: Why do solar systems look mostly 'flat'?
answers: Solar systems look mostly 'flat' because of the law of conservation of total angular momentum.
This law states that the total amount of spinning in any isolated system, such as the Solar System, will always remain constant.
Therefore, when particles within the solar system collide, the up and down motion of the particles cancels out and the particles lose energy in crashing and clumping.
This means that the whole mass of the solar system must continue spinning, resulting in the cloud losing its loft and flattening into a spinning, two dimensional, disk shape.
This is why solar systems look mostly 'flat' today.

question: If you put glasses from someone with dioptry, do you see like they see without them?
answers: No, putting on glasses from someone with a dioptry will not make you see like they do without them.
Dioptry is a unit of measurement used in eyeglass prescriptions to indicate how powerful a lens is needed to properly focus light on a person's retina.
Different people have different vision needs, and what works for one person may not work for another.
For example, someone with nearsightedness may need a negative diopter, while someone with farsightedness may need a positive diopter.
Additionally, different people have different ranges of "sweet spot" for bringing close vision into sharp focus.
This range changes from person to person and is determined by the diopter strength that correctly focuses light on their retina.
Furthermore, someone's diopter needs will also depend on how far away they are from the material they are looking at.
For example, if someone is working at their desk and their computer monitor is 24 inches away, they will need a weaker power than they would for reading, which typically happens within 14-18 inches.
Therefore, putting on glasses from someone with a dioptry will not make you see like they do without them.

question: How has technological growth increased so exponentially in the last 50 years?
answers: Technology has grown exponentially in the last 50 years due to the observation known as Moore's Law.
This observation states that the number of transistors on integrated circuits doubles approximately every two years.
This has had a tremendous impact on the performance and cost of technology, as increased transistors in smaller spaces has made processing power more powerful, energy efficient, and more affordable.
The growth of technology has impacted many industries and has spawned whole new ones.
It has enabled the internet, social media, data analytics, and many other innovations.
It has also changed how cities, transportation, healthcare, education, and energy production are approached.
Moore's Law has been the foundational force behind this technological growth and is still applicable today, even over 50 years after its original observation.

question: what is 'Magnetic moment'
answers: Magnetic moment, also referred to as magnetic dipole moment, is the measure of the object’s tendency to align with a magnetic field.
It is a vector quantity, meaning that it has both magnitude and direction.
It is defined as the torque of an object to the magnetic field, and the direction is determined by the right-hand-rule.
In most cases, the magnetic moments of electrons with opposite spins will cancel each other out, and the atom will not have a magnetic field.
However, in some cases, the magnetic moments of some electrons are not canceled, and the atom will have a magnetic moment.
The magnetic moment of an object can be affected by the tilt of its rotational axis, as seen with the planets Saturn, Earth, and Jupiter.

question: What is the difference between sigma bonds and pi bonds?
answers: The main difference between sigma bonds and pi bonds is the way in which they are formed.
Sigma bonds are formed by the linear or co-axial overlapping of the atomic orbitals of two atoms, while pi bonds are formed by the parallel or lateral overlapping of the atomic orbitals.
Sigma bonds are stronger than pi bonds, and they can be formed between both s and p orbitals whereas pi bonds are mostly formed between p and d orbitals.
Single covalent bonds between atoms are sigma bonds, and when there are multiple bonds between atoms, pi bonds can be seen.
Furthermore, pi bonds result in unsaturated molecules, whereas sigma bonds allow for free rotation of atoms, whereas pi bonds restrict the free rotation.

question: What is austerity?
answers: Austerity is a state of extreme self-discipline or minimalistic living, often employed in the context of a national economy.
It is the noun form of the adjective austere, which means extremely stern or strict, or without any luxuries.
When austerity measures are implemented during times of economic crisis, services and access to certain goods may be scaled back by the government in order to help curb the rising debt.
This often involves cutting back on non-essential spending, increasing taxes, and reducing the size of the public sector.
By doing this, the government hopes to reduce its budget deficit, improve financial stability, and potentially stimulate economic growth.

question: Why do undocumented immigrants returning to Mexico drive down wages there, but proponents of relaxed immigration say they don't do the same here?
answers: The debate over the effect of immigration on wages is a complicated one, as economists use different empirical methods to measure the impact of immigration on wages.

While half of the 15 industries with the highest percentage of foreign-born workers are low-wage service industries, a recent analysis commissioned by the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine found "little evidence that immigration significantly affects the overall employment levels of native-born workers."
However, there are certain factors that may contribute to the discrepancy between the impact of immigration on wages in the U.S. and Mexico.
First, many immigrants in the U.S. send portions of their income out of the domestic economy in the form of remittances.
This is not a factor in Mexico, where most immigrants do not have access to the same remittance channels.
Additionally, migrants in the U.S. are paid their marginal product, meaning that much of their value added to production directly benefits the native population.
This is unlike in Mexico, where undocumented immigrants returning to the country often face lower wages than their U.S. counterparts.

Therefore, while proponents of relaxed immigration may argue that immigrants do not drive down wages in the U.S., the same cannot be said for Mexico, where undocumented immigrants returning to the country often face lower wages than their U.S. counterparts.

question: Why does it seem like when I watch something the second time around, it goes by faster than the first time I watched it?
answers: It seems like when we watch something the second time around it goes by faster than the first time we watched it because our minds have already processed the information the first time we watched it.
This means that our minds don't have to take in and process as much information the second time around, so time appears to pass more quickly.

This phenomenon can be explained by the research of psychologist Robert Ornstein, who found that when people are exposed to more information, such as double the number of clicking noises, they perceive the time period to be longer.
This suggests that the more information our minds take in and process, the slower time feels like it is going.
Therefore, when we watch something the second time around, our minds are not processing as much novel information, so time passes more quickly.

question: How can a vehicle's air filter effect its gas mileage?
answers: A vehicle's air filter can have a significant effect on its gas mileage.
A dirty air filter can reduce airflow to the engine and cause it to work harder, resulting in decreased fuel efficiency, higher emissions, and possibly a loss of engine power.
Studies have suggested that replacing a dirty air filter can increase fuel mileage on older, carburated cars by up to 14 percent, and on modern fuel-injected cars by up to 11 percent.
In addition, changing a clogged air filter can potentially increase acceleration by 6 to 11 percent and result in fuel savings of up to 15¢ per gallon.
A clean air filter improves air flow to the engine and increases engine performance and gas mileage.
On the other hand, a clogged cabin air filter can lead to under-performance of the A/C system, causing weak air flow from the cabin vents, as well as unwanted, unfiltered air in the cabin.
Similarly, a mucked-up fuel filter can lead to a weakened fuel supply to injectors, a reduction in engine power, poor acceleration, and lousy fuel economy.

question: Why do benches empty when there is a fight in baseball?
answers: Bench-clearing brawls in baseball occur when all of the players on both teams leave their dugouts, bullpens, or benches and charge the playing area in order to fight one another or try to break up a fight.
This can happen when a player takes offense to a play or an umpire's call, or even when a pitcher throws a brushback pitch at a hitter.
Although it was more common in the past, when players were often high on drugs, bench-clearing brawls still occur today as players take offense or retaliate against perceived injustices on the field.
These fights can also be a way for teams to show solidarity for one another and provide support to a teammate in a time of need.
The penalties for leaving the bench can range from nothing to severe, but these brawls remain an integral part of baseball culture.

question: Why is eating burnt food bad for you?
answers: Eating burnt food can be bad for you because of the potential carcinogenic compounds that are produced when the food is cooked at high temperatures.
Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and heterocyclic amines (HCAs) are two chemicals that are formed when fat and juices drip onto flames while frying, baking, or grilling meat.
PAHs are also formed when meat is smoked or charred.
HCAs form when amino acids and creatine react at high cooking temperatures and are formed in greater quantities when meats are overcooked or blackened.
Studies have shown that these chemicals can increase the risk of certain types of cancer in animals when they are exposed to large doses.

Additionally, the Joint Food and Agriculture Organization/World Health Organization Expert Committee on Food Additives (JECFA) concluded that acrylamide, which forms as part of the Maillard reaction when certain foods are cooked at high temperatures, is a human health concern.
Therefore, it is best to avoid eating burnt food, as it can contain potentially harmful carcinogenic compounds.

question: How did people manipulate photographs before computers?
answers: People manipulated photographs before computers in a variety of ways.

Traditional photographic prints could be altered using methods such as retouching with ink, paint, airbrushing, or scratching Polaroids during developing (Polaroid art); negatives could be manipulated while still in the camera using double-exposure techniques, or in the darkroom by piecing photos or negatives together.

Some darkroom manipulations involved techniques such as bleaching to artfully lighten or totally wash-out parts of the photograph, or hand coloring for aesthetic purposes or to mimic a fine art painting.

Art directors, graphic designers, and publishers would labor long hours over images, attempting to perfect skin, materials, and other issues which, today, would be easily whisked away with the click of a mouse.
Tools like paint, erasers, airbrushes, and other art supplies were necessary in any studio, as was a steady hand and a keen eye for color and shadow.

In the 19th century, photographers also resorted to manual interventions to compensate for the early medium’s technical limitations, enlivening their pictures with powdered pigment, watercolor and oil paint.

To overcome the problem of blotchy blue skies, many landscape photographers would make two separate negatives — one exposed for the land, the other for the sky — and print them together on a single sheet of paper.

question: how is a heavy duty clog cleaner able to work on a significant amount of standing water?
answers: Heavy duty clog cleaners are able to work on a significant amount of standing water because they are typically heavier than water.
This means that they are able to move through the standing water to reach the clog.
Caustic drain cleaners contain substances such as lye and caustic potash, which are bases and release hydroxide ions that create the reaction that clears the clog.
Acid drain cleaners contain high concentrations of sulfuric acid or hydrochloric acid, which increase hydronium ions in a solution and attract electrons from the clog.
Oxidizing drain cleaners contain substances such as household bleach, peroxides and nitrates which cause the organic material of the clog to lose electrons and become oxidized.
All of these chemical reactions involve moving electrons and generate heat, which is necessary to melt congealed grease and dissolve the clog.

question: Why does lying down reduce my urge to puke when I feel like puking?
answers: Lying down can reduce your urge to vomit when you feel like puking because it helps keep acid or food from moving up into your esophagus.
This can prevent the symptoms of heartburn, regurgitation, and nausea that are associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
When you lie down, your head should be propped up about 12 inches above your feet to prevent the acid or food from moving up.
This simple action can help relieve the urge to vomit and reduce the symptoms of GERD.
Additionally, the nausea may linger if stomach acid backs up into the throat, so it's important to remain propped up in order to reduce the symptoms.

question: Why do people in all old voice recordings have the same "old timey" accents?
answers: People in old voice recordings have the same "old timey" Mid-Atlantic accent because of the technological limitations of the early days of radio and sound film.
This accent was a blend of American English and British English which favoured neither and was consciously learned by actors to be understood on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean.
This accent was also known as American Theater Standard or American stage speech.
The poor quality of microphone and loudspeakers at the time meant the speaker needed to enunciate very clearly and use a lot of emphases to ensure their audience could understand them.
This gave rise to a clipped, nasal, "all-treble" acoustic quality.
After World War II, the teaching of this pronunciation declined sharply and the American version of a ‘posh’ accent has all but disappeared.
According to Professor Jay O’Berski, this nasally, clipped pronunciation is a vestige from the early days of radio.
Receivers had very little bass technology at the time, and it was very difficult – if not impossible – to hear bass tones on your home device, thus giving rise to the unique "old timey" accent.

question: Why will a file load to 99% with no problem then hang for what seems like forever?
answers: A file loading to 99% with no problem then hanging for what seems like forever can be caused by a number of factors.
It could be due to the capacity of the hard drive, as large files may take longer to transfer due to the amount of data that needs to be processed.

question: The Lean Six Sigma Methodology
answers: The Lean Six Sigma methodology is an effective problem-solving tool designed to improve customer satisfaction.
It uses data and analysis to reduce waste and errors and create continuous process improvement with low defects.
The aim of the methodology is to make a process 99.99996% defect-free.
The first step is to clarify the objectives of the business or project.

Then, the DMAIC process is used to define the specific needs, measure the main characteristics of existing processes, analyze the collected data, improve each of the processes, and control the methodology in the future to maintain a low level of errors in the organization.
The Lean Six Sigma methodology can also be used when you are determined to diminish the mistakes, errors, or defective products by first identifying the problems.
This highly effective methodology will help organizations to improve their processes, reduce mistakes, and create higher customer satisfaction.

question: What causes us to tear up when we cut onions? Is there a way to prevent this?
answers: When we cut onions, the outer layer of the skin is broken, releasing enzymes and sulfenic acid which combine to form propanethial S-oxide, an irritating gas.
This gas is a lachrymatory agent, meaning that it produces tears when it comes into contact with the eye.
The nerves in each eye detect the lachrymatory agent and generate tears in an effort to flush it out and protect the eyes.
This is why we tear up when we cut onions, although the burning and irritation are only temporary and do not cause any long-term effects.
To prevent this from happening, there are several options.
Goggles can be worn to prevent the gas from reaching the eyes while cutting onions, although they are not really necessary.
Another option is to cut the onions in a bowl of water, which will reduce the amount of gas exposure.
Alternatively, eye drops can be used to help lubricate or rinse the eyes, and dilute the gas exposure.

question: Why do police officers have bullet proof vests for covering vital organs when often times they leave their heads unprotected?
answers: Police officers often have bullet proof vests for covering vital organs because their heads are unfortunately left unprotected in some dangerous situations.
This is due to the impracticality of wearing a ballistic helmet for every second of duty.

Officers are continually being called upon to respond quickly to threats on their own, and in the case of an active shooter, it can be argued that a tactically sound choice for the officer would be to go to the trunk of the squad car to get kitted up (hard plates, rifle, helmet) before rushing in with nothing more than a pistol and soft armor.
That ballistic helmet or hard armor might mean the difference between the police officer staying in the fight and eliminating the threat or becoming another casualty themselves.
There are three main options when choosing a ballistic helmet; PASGT helmets, Below The Ear Cut helmets (MICH/ACH/ECH/LWH) and High Cut helmets (FAST).
These helmets provide the most ballistic coverage for police officers, however, the extra weight and the discomfort of headset use with these helmets can be a drawback.
Despite this, having a ballistic helmet is essential for protecting vital organs and can be the difference between life and death in a dangerous situation.

question: Explain: Having a "stone" in your saliva gland.
answers: Having a stone in your saliva gland, also known as sialolithiasis, is a condition where hardened mineral deposits form in the salivary glands.
It is more common in people aged 30 to 60 and men are more likely to get salivary stones than women.
The cause is not known, but factors such as dehydration, trauma to the mouth, smoking and gum disease have been associated with salivary stone formation.

Most stones affect the submandibular glands located at the floor of the mouth, but they can also affect the parotid glands, located on the inside of the cheeks, or the sublingual glands, which are under the tongue.
The stones are mostly composed of calcium and can block the flow of saliva into the mouth.
Symptoms of salivary stones can include pain, swelling, fever, difficulty swallowing, dry mouth and bad breath.

Home remedies for getting rid of salivary stones include sucking on citrus fruits or hard candies, drinking plenty of fluids, gentle massage of the affected area, taking medications such as ibuprofen and acetaminophen, and sucking on ice cubes.
If these treatments do not work, a doctor may need to remove the stone surgically.

question: Why does smoking tobacco cause cancer, but smoking marijuana does not?
answers: Smoking tobacco causes cancer because it contains at least 70 carcinogenic chemicals that can damage DNA.
When these chemicals get into the bloodstream, they are carried to all parts of the body, which can cause cells to grow abnormally and lead to cancer.
While smoking marijuana also has some of the same cancer-causing substances as tobacco, there is no clear evidence that it increases the risk of lung cancer or any other type of cancer.
However, due to the potential risks it poses to lung health, experts strongly advise against smoking cannabis and tobacco products.
More research is needed to determine whether smoking cannabis increases a person’s risk for cancer, and until then, it is best to avoid smoking either substance.

question: How can water boil below 100°C?
answers: Water can boil below 100°C in high altitude areas due to the lower atmospheric pressure.
At higher altitudes, the atmospheric pressure pushing down on water is reduced, allowing the water to boil at lower temperatures.
This means that food cooks at a lower temperature, despite the fact that the water is boiling.

The boiling point of water is reduced as the altitude increases, with water at sea level boiling at 212 degrees Fahrenheit, while water at 5,000 feet boiling at 203 degrees F and water at 10,000 feet boiling at 194 degrees F. This lower boiling point is due to the fact that water molecules have an easier time escaping off the surface when the air pressure above them is less.
As a result, when heated, the water reaches its boiling point more quickly and at a lower temperature than at lower altitudes.

question: why does the file size of digital photos vary when the pixel count doesn't change?
answers: The file size of digital photos can vary even when the pixel count doesn't change because the image quality, image size, and color depth all affect the file size.
The image quality setting dictates how much compression is used to encode the file and thus affects the file size.
Higher image quality settings use less compression and thus create a larger file size.
The image size setting affects the physical size and resolution of the image, and thus affects the file size.
A higher image size setting means a larger picture and bigger file size.
Finally, the color depth affects the file size.
A higher color depth setting assigns more bits of red, green and blue to each pixel, resulting in a larger file size.

question: after World War II, what changes did Germany make to it's own political system to ensure a dictator figure could never take power again?
answers: After World War II, Germany underwent a major overhaul of its political system in an effort to prevent another dictatorship from taking power.
The country was divided into four separate zones, each governed by one of the Allied Powers and France, in order to treat Germany as a single economic zone.
By 1949, the Western half of Germany, also known as the Federal Republic of Germany, had taken on the model of a Western democracy, while the Soviet-controlled Eastern side was a socialist state.
Prime Minister Hans Modrow headed a caretaker government which shared power with the new, democratically oriented parties.
On 7 December 1989, an agreement was reached to hold free elections in May 1990 and rewrite the East German constitution, which was advanced to 18 March due to an erosion of state authority.
In early February 1990, the Modrow government's proposal for a unified, neutral German state was rejected by Chancellor Kohl, who affirmed that a unified Germany must be a member of NATO.
On 18 March, the first free elections were held in East Germany, and a government led by Lothar de Maizière (CDU) was formed under a policy of expeditious unification with West Germany.
The freely elected representatives of the Volkskammer held their first session on 5 April, and East Germany peacefully evolved from a communist to a democratically elected government.
The conclusion of the final settlement cleared the way for the unification of East and West Germany.
Formal political union occurred on 3 October 1990, preceded by the GDR declaring its accession to the Federal Republic through Article 23 of West Germany's Basic Law.

The Unification Treaty of 30 August 1990 was also voted into their constitutions by both the West German Bundestag and the East German Volkskammer on 20 September 1990, which simultaneously extinguished the GDR and affected fundamental amendments to the West German Basic Law.
These changes were designed to ensure that a dictator figure could never take power again.

The separation of the country into four zones, the establishment of a democratically-oriented government, and the unification of East and West Germany all helped to create a more stable and democratic political system that would prevent the rise of another dictator.

question: Why is it harder to fall asleep in noisy environments?
answers: It is harder to fall asleep in noisy environments because our brains are always on alert for sudden noises, which can cause us to jolt awake and ruin our sleep.
Our brains are programmed to respond to sudden, loud noises, as they could be perceived as a potential danger.
This means that when we hear sudden noises, even if the volume is not that high, our brains can’t relax and we stay on alert.
This can be especially difficult in noisy environments where there are frequent, sudden changes in volume, such as a police siren or loud revelers.
To combat this, people can use white noise generators to create a continuous sound at a consistent volume that is just above the level of normal conversation.
This can help to minimize the impact of sudden spikes in volume and help us to relax and fall asleep.

question: How do animals deal with getting prickles/thorns/splinters etc in their feet?
answers: Animals have developed a variety of methods for dealing with getting pricks, thorns, and splinters in their feet.
For example, the Thorny Devil is a species of lizard known for its ability to collect and transport water through its skin.
This adaptation helps protect the lizard from getting pricked by thorns and splinters, as the water serves as a buffer between the lizard and the foreign object.
Similarly, the spiny lobster is protected by spines that line its antennae and point forward along its shell, providing a layer of protection against thorns and splinters.
The crown-of-thorns sea star is also spiny and has adapted to protect itself in this way.
In other cases, when an animal does get a splinter in its foot, the best course of action is to remove it as soon as possible.
This can be done by washing the affected area with warm, soapy water and then using tweezers to remove the splinter.
Afterwards, the area should be washed again with either warm, soapy water or a disinfectant to ensure that no bacteria remain.
If the splinter isn't removed, it is likely that the body will try to push it out on its own.

question: How come some people have lovely handwriting and others don't?
answers: The answer to why some people have lovely handwriting, and others do not, is multi-faceted and can be attributed to a variety of factors.
Firstly, handwriting is often taught at a younger age, when the fine motor skills of girls are more developed than boys, leading to women being perceived as naturally better at penmanship.

Additionally, those with poor or illegible handwriting usually haven't properly trained the correct muscle groups in their hands, arms, and shoulders, and so taking the opportunity to write things by hand whenever possible will help build up these muscles for smooth and easy writing.

Furthermore, pre-writing skills, consisting of an age-appropriate sequence of lines and shapes which toddlers and preschoolers learn in order to eventually form letters and numbers, are essential for the development of good handwriting.
Developing hand-eye coordination with lots of gross motor hand-eye exercises can help in this regard.

Lastly, practicing the alphabet by filling up lines with each letter of the alphabet in lower and uppercase, and focusing on the areas of improvement highlighted by a handwriting analysis, can further help in improving one's handwriting.

question: How were continents, countries and coastlines mapped out prior to the invention of satellites?
answers: Prior to the invention of satellites, the primary means of mapping out continents, countries and coastlines was through the use of portolan charts.
These charts were created by sailors and other mariners who used their observations of the coastline to compile detailed maps of the area.
Portolan charts were made from observations taken from boats, and relied on dead reckoning (DR) to advance positions on the map.
This method required that the navigator measure the direction of travel and have an accurate estimate of the speed of the boat.
This method was not very accurate, and was often inaccurate over long distances.
In 1569, the Belgian geographer and cartographer Gerardus Mercator created a method for presenting a spherical world on a flat map.

This mapmaking technique, though it stretched and compressed landmarks and distances between them, had the great advantage that a straight compass course was represented by a straight line on the map.
This made it easier for sailors to navigate and plot their course from one place to another.
Another method that was used to map out coasts was known as piloting.
This method used bearings from reference points on accurate maps to determine the position of points along the coastline.
This allowed for much more accurate navigation than dead reckoning.
Overall, prior to the invention of satellites, a variety of methods were used to map out continents, countries and coastlines.
These methods, while not as accurate as satellite data, provided a way for sailors and cartographers to accurately navigate and chart the continents, countries and coastlines of the world.

question: Seismologists: How do you determine whether an earthquake was naturally occurring or if it was human induced?
answers: Seismologists determine whether an earthquake was naturally occurring or human induced by analyzing the pattern of the seismic waves and the source of the fault rupture.
According to a recent study by Stanford researchers, induced earthquakes and natural earthquakes in the central U.S. are inherently similar, and can be predicted using the same framework.
This suggests that the stresses released by both kinds of earthquakes are similar, meaning that the same tools might be used to predict both.
By studying the characteristics of the seismic waves, researchers can identify the source of the fault rupture and determine whether the quake was human-induced or naturally occurring.
Additionally, researchers can use their knowledge of the surrounding environment and geological features to identify the potential cause of the quake.

For instance, in areas with oil and gas production, it is more likely that an earthquake was human-induced, whereas in more remote and unpopulated areas, it may be more likely that the quake was naturally occurring.

question: As a person with astigmatism, why is it when I squint my eyes a little I can see a little clearer?
answers: As a person with astigmatism, squinting can help you see a little clearer because it changes the shape of your eye, making the pupil smaller and letting less light in, allowing more of the focused central light rays to reach your retina.
This creates a “pinhole effect”, where only a small amount of focused central light rays are allowed into the eye, and unfocused light rays in the periphery are prevented from reaching the retina.
This is similar to the way a larger aperture works in a camera, where a smaller hole lets less light in, with better focus.
Additionally, this decreases the amount of light that enters the eye, reducing the impact on the retina and allowing the object you’re viewing to look sharper.
The combination of these two mechanisms allows for a more focused image and better vision.

question: Why can I eat mold on a cheese, but not on any other foods?
answers: Eating mold on certain types of cheese is generally considered safe for healthy adults, as the mold used to make cheeses such as Brie and Camembert is not considered harmful.

However, it is important to avoid other soft cheeses and cheeses made with unpasteurized milk, as these can be dangerous for those with weakened immune systems, older adults, pregnant women, infants and young children.

In contrast, mold found on other types of food is not safe for consumption, as the mold may have tentacles that have penetrated deep into the food, contaminating even the parts that appear to be mold-free.
Eating mold can produce toxic substances, called mycotoxins, which can cause respiratory problems, allergic reactions, and even cancer-causing aflatoxins.
It is usually easy to spot mold, as it appears as a blue or green discoloration and can grow a hairy coat if left long enough.
Hard block cheeses like parmesan, cheddar, or Swiss are the exceptions, as the mold generally won’t penetrate deep into the product.
However, it is important to cut away an inch of cheese all the way around the spot to ensure the mold has not spread to other foods, as inhaling mold spores can also be dangerous.

question: Shutter Speed and Aperture.
answers: Shutter speed and aperture are two of the most important camera settings to understand when it comes to capturing a great photograph.
Shutter speed is the length of time the camera shutter is open to expose light into the camera sensor.
Shutter speeds are typically measured in fractions of a second and can be adjusted to capture low-light or night photography.
Fast shutter speeds help to freeze motion and slow shutter speeds allow more light to enter the camera sensor.
Aperture is the size of the hole within the lens, through which light passes into the camera body.
The larger the hole, the more light passes to the camera sensor, and it also determines the depth of field, which is the portion of a scene that appears to be sharp.
By changing the aperture, you can adjust the depth of field, while changing the shutter speed alters the appearance of moving objects.
Therefore, understanding how to adjust these two settings can help you to create stunning photos.

question: What exactly is going on with my computer when it crashes?
answers: When your computer crashes, it is usually the result of an error in either the operating system software or the hardware.
Common software errors include corrupted system registry files, disorganized files, malicious software, and too little available memory.
Hardware errors can be caused by overheating, outdated drivers, or faulty hardware components, such as the CPU fan, RAM, hard drive, or power supply.
Overheating can be caused by the CPU fan wearing down, a lack of proper ventilation, or dust accumulation.
Outdated drivers can lead to incompatibilities between hardware components, resulting in a crash.
Faulty hardware components can also cause crashes, and should be tested and replaced if necessary.

question: Dictionary tells me agnostic means "I think it can't be proven" but commonly in North America people seem to use it to mean "kinda don't believe in God". Why is that?
answers: The term agnostic is often used in North America to mean “kinda don’t believe in God”, even though the dictionary definition is “I think it can’t be proven”.
This likely stems from the origin of the term in the 19th century when it was first used by Thomas Henry Huxley.
Huxley was a proponent of Charles Darwin’s theory of evolution and did not subscribe to religious beliefs.

He coined the phrase as an antithetical response to Gnosticism, a religious ideology in the first and second centuries that suggested that the material world was ungodly while the spirit world was the better choice.
Huxley believed that nature was too diverse to have been created and that natural selection provided a better explanation provable by evidence.
He argued that it is wrong to claim a phenomenon is a definite truth unless logical evidence is provided, and so agnosticism simply states that no one can know for sure if God exists or not.
This idea of unknowability has grown over the years, and in North America has become a sort of default opinion for those who do not want to commit to either a belief in or disbelief of God.
It is a way of expressing the uncertainty that comes with trying to answer the complex and unanswerable question of whether God exists or not.
Agnosticism is a way of saying that no one can be sure, and so it is best to reserve judgment.
By using the term to mean “kinda don’t believe in God”, people are able to express their uncertainty around the matter without committing to either side.

question: Why is it that a fully buffered YouTube video will buffer again from where you click on the progress bar when you skip a few seconds ahead?
answers: The reason why a fully buffered YouTube video will buffer again from where you click on the progress bar when you skip a few seconds ahead is due to the way YouTube's servers and other infrastructure are set up.
YouTube's servers and other infrastructure are designed to load the entire video at once and store it in memory for quick retrieval when requested by a user.
This means that when you seek ahead to a different part of the video, the servers need to retrieve the requested data from their stored memory and transfer it to your device.
That's why you'll experience buffering when you skip ahead in a YouTube video, because the servers are still retrieving the data needed to watch the video.

Additionally, if there is heavy traffic on YouTube and the servers are already busy serving other users, this can further impede the server's ability to quickly retrieve and transfer the requested data, resulting in further buffering.

answers: When you invest in a stock, your money first goes to the stock exchange, where the stock is listed.
You can purchase shares of the stock from a broker or through an online trading platform.
When you buy a share of the stock, you become a shareholder and now own a piece of the company.
The money you paid for the stock goes to the company, which can use it to fund operations, pay expenses, and expand their business.
As the company's business grows and their stock price increases, your shares of the stock increase in value, meaning you can make a profit when you decide to sell them.
When you do, the money you get from selling the stock goes back into your pocket.

question: Why doesn't it thunder during snow storms?
answers: Generally, thunder during snow storms is not common because it requires very specific conditions in the atmosphere.
It requires a large temperature difference across the storm, which is often not present in a snow storm.
If a storm has access to warmer air to the southeast of the storm's center, convection can increase, allowing for a thundersnow event.
Additionally, thundersnow also requires very strong vertical motion, which can be created by an approaching strong mid- and upper-level trough.
Lake-effect snowstorms can also sometimes develop thunder and lightning, as the clouds have a narrow shape more like ordinary thunderstorms.
However, these occurrences are still rare, and thunder snow remains an uncommon phenomenon.

question: if I need pain relief, how do I know whether to choose between aspirin, Tylenol, Advil, etc.? They are all labeled as pain relievers.
answers: Deciding which pain reliever to choose depends on the type of pain you are experiencing and the severity of your symptoms.
Acetaminophen (Tylenol) is a good choice for mild to moderate pain, such as headaches, arthritis pain, or a fever.
It is less likely to cause stomach issues than other OTC pain-relievers.
Ibuprofen (Advil) and Naproxen are both non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) that reduce fevers, pain, and inflammation.
They are good choices for treating menstrual cramps, headaches, toothaches, backaches, arthritis, muscle strains, and gout.
Aspirin is also an NSAID that relieves pain.
It may be a good choice for treating headaches, toothaches, colds, and fever.
If you are unsure which medication to take, you should consult with your doctor or pharmacist.

question: How would a bank make money if I deposited 1 billion dollars into my savings, considering the interest would be millions?
answers: If a customer deposited 1 billion dollars into a savings account with a 1.50% APY, the bank would make an estimated $15 million in a year's time.
However, this is not the only way banks make money with the money you deposit.
Banks also make money from account fees, ATM fees, penalty charges, commissions, and application fees.

For example, the bank may charge a fee for maintaining the account, a fee for using an out-of-network ATM, a penalty fee for late payments or overdrafts, a commission for investment trades, and a loan origination or application fee.
All of these fees are added to the bank's profits and add to the millions of dollars they make from the interest of the deposit.
Therefore, if a customer deposited 1 billion dollars into a savings account, the bank would make a considerable amount of money in a year's time, not just from the interest but also from other fees.

question: How does evolution occur and how did the first living organisms come about
answers: Evolution is the process of change over time, and it occurs through a series of adaptations that help organisms better survive and reproduce in their environment.
The process of evolution is often driven by natural selection and random genetic mutation.
Natural selection is the process by which the traits of an organism become more or less common in a population over time, depending on how well they help the organism survive and reproduce.
Random genetic mutation is the process by which new genetic information is created and passed on from one generation to the next, allowing organisms to adapt to new environments.
The first living organisms likely came about through a process called abiogenesis.
Abiogenesis is the process by which life is thought to have arisen from non-living matter, such as chemicals and gases.

In 1952, Miller conducted an experiment to investigate the origin of life, in which he subjected four chemicals—boiling water, hydrogen gas, ammonia, and methane—to repeated electric shocks, simulating the lightning strikes that would have been present on early Earth.
Through this experiment, Miller found that the mixture of chemicals produced two amino acids—glycine and alanine—which are the building blocks of life.
As these building blocks continued to accumulate, they eventually developed into more complex structures, such as microbes.
Cyanobacteria evolved at least 2.4 billion years ago, becoming Earth’s first photo-synthesizers and releasing oxygen as a result.
This catalyzed a dramatic rise in oxygen levels and made the environment less hospitable for other microbes.
These microbes eventually evolved into eukaryotic cells, which contain organelles and nuclei to package their DNA.
Cells began living together and evolved into the first animals, which DNA evidence suggests evolved around 800 million years ago.
Through this gradual process of abiogenesis, natural selection, and random genetic mutation, the first living organisms were created.

question: If I am not supposed to clean my ears deep with a q-tip, why does it feel so good and sometimes clear my sinuses?
answers: While it may feel good to clean the inside of your ear with a cotton swab, it is not recommended due to the risk of injury and infection.
Your ears naturally produce earwax, which helps to keep them from getting too dry, traps dirt, and prevents bacteria from entering deeper into your ear.
Using a cotton swab to try to clear earwax can actually push the earwax deeper in, leading to a buildup and resulting in symptoms such as pain, a feeling of fullness in the ear, and muffled hearing.
Furthermore, using a q-tip too deep can potentially rupture your eardrum or scratch the skin of the ear canal, resulting in bleeding or infection.
Additionally, some people may experience a stimulation of the Vagus nerve, which runs from the brain to the butt, when they clean their ears with a q-tip.
Although cleaning your ears with a q-tip may initially feel good and clear your sinuses, it is best to avoid the potential risks associated with it.

question: Why are so many people choosing longboards over traditional skateboards these days? Are they easier to ride? What is the benefit?
answers: In recent years, longboards have become increasingly popular amongst riders, as they offer a variety of benefits that traditional skateboards do not.
Longboards are typically much longer and wider than skateboards, and they also have larger, softer wheels.
This makes them much more flexible and easier to ride for beginners than skateboards, as they are less likely to bounce if you do an ollie or other trick.
The wider trucks also provide more stability at higher speeds, and the flat design of the nose and tail make it easier for riders to stay in control.
Additionally, longboards can be up to 59 inches long, which allows riders to go faster and have more control.
All in all, longboards are a great option for riders of all skill levels, as they offer a great balance of speed and stability, as well as being easier to ride than traditional skateboards.

question: If most of what we taste is determined by smell, why do some things that smell good (cologne, perfume, soap, etc.) taste bad? (re-post/ rephrased from /r/explainlikeimfive)
answers: While it is true that smell plays a big role in determining what we taste, it is not the only factor.
Taste buds are responsible for detecting the five modalities of taste - salt, sweet, sour, bitter, and umami.

While many fragrances like cologne, perfume, and soap smell good, they contain ingredients that are not meant to be ingested and, in fact, they may contain toxic alcohols that are used as preservatives and stabilizers.
When these ingredients are tasted, they can cause unpleasant sensations such as a burning or bitter taste.
Additionally, many fragrances contain irritants that can cause a stinging sensation on the tongue.
Thus, even though a fragrance may smell pleasant, it does not necessarily mean that it will taste good.

question: Why are items always priced ending in ".99" instead of ".00"?
answers: It is a type of psychological pricing, where the .99 at the end of the price makes it seem like a better deal than a product with a price ending in .00.
The way our brains process prices means that when we see a price of $9.99, we associate it as part of the $9–$9.99 “range” rather than the $10–$10.99 “range”.

Additionally, the .99 alone serves to make an item appear to be on sale, as price-conscious consumers have become conditioned to believe that they are getting a good deal when they buy something with a price ending in .99 even if the markdown is minimal.
This is especially effective if you’re just quickly perusing several prices in a row; the first number will definitely stand out to you more.

Furthermore, ending a price in .99 is based on the theory that, because we read from left to right, the first digit of the price resonates with us the most, so shoppers are more likely to buy a product for $4.99 than an identical one for $5.

Finally, the .99 trick takes advantage of the way our brains process prices and the fact that we tend to attempt to reduce the amount of effort expended on making product decisions, especially with lower-cost items.
